bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 12, 1875

div1.p: This series of endorsements by various members of the political and military community supports Reed's desire to join the Surgeon General's staff. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 12, 1875
div1.opener:
3298.
WAR DEPARTMENT
RECEIVED APR 12
1875
1769. SGO. 1875
Harrisonburg, Va.,
April 12, 1875.
Hon. John T. Harris
Request assignment of Asst.
Surg. Walter Reed, who has
recently USA passed the Army
Med. Ext. Board, to tem-
porary duty in N.Y. Harbor,
or at Fort Monroe, or any
fort on the Atlantic Coast
north of N.C.
Surgeon General,
for remarks recd. Apr.9/75.
2nd Endorsement.
Surgeon General's Office,
April 19th 1875.
div1.p:
Respectfully returned to
the Hon. the Secretary of
War. Dr. Walter Reed has
been examined and approved
by the Army Medical Board
in session in New York City,
for appointment as Assistant
Surgeon, but has not yet
been appointed.

It is contemplated by this
office to request that he be
assigned, after appointment,
to temporary duty at one of
the larger military posts
for instruction.

He declined employment
as Acting Assistant Surgeon
until such time as he could
be appointed Assistant Surgeon,
but if he now desires to go
on duty a contract will be
made with him for the
purpose above mentioned.

closer.signed:
J.K. Barnes
Surgeon General,
U.S. Army.

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 12, 1875
div1.opener:
Harrisonburg Va
Aprl. 12, 75.
Hon. W.W. Belknap
Secy War
Sir:
div1.p:
My young
friend, Ast. Surgeon Walter
Reed, who passed the ex-
amination before the Army
Med. Board in February last,
desires, when his appointment is made, to be assigned to
temporary duty in N.Y. Harbor.
If that is not practicable,
then to Fortress Monroe or
any fort on the atlantic
coast north of N.C.

I pray you will not
regard this as any intru-
sion or attempt to interfere
with your prerogative, but
as Dr. Reed has never been
assigned to duty, it occurs
to him, that it may be
wholly immaterial with you
where he will begin service.

I shall take it as a personal
compliment to myself as
well as a great kindness to
my friend, if you can
gratify his wishes.
I have the honor to
be very
div1.closer:
Respectfully your
Friend & ObSevt John T. Harris 7 Dst. Va.
Dr. Reed declined [unclear] by
letter of Feby.18.1875

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 13, 1875
div1.opener:
Lynnwood-
April 13th 1875.
Hon. Sec. of War,
My dear Sir,
div1.p:
Doct. Reed, is
auscious to be assigned to duty
in the New York Harbor, or at
Fort Monroe. If compatible
with your view of duty, I would
be pleased to have you gratify
the Doct. in this matter, and
I am sure he would give entire
satisfaction in the position.
div1.closer:
Very Respectfully, and,
truly yours John F. Lewis. Hon. W.W. Belknap-
City of Washington-
D.C.
Dr W. Reed passed his examina[tion]
before the Army Med. Board in Feb-
ruary last, & is awaiting his appoint[ment.]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 12, 1875
div1.p:
Refers letter of Hon. Jno F. Lewis, (Lynnwood, Va),
April 13, 1875,) requesting assignment of Asst
Surg Walter Reed to duty in New York
Harbor, or Fort Monroe

Respectfully returned to the Hon. the
Secretary of War, attention invited
to the endorsement from this office
of the 19th instant, upon communication
from the Hon. Jno. F. Harris, requesting
the assignment of Dr. Walter Reed, to duty
in New York Harbor, or any post on the
Atlantic coast, north of North Carolina.

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, April 21, 1875
div1.opener:
[unclear]
3298.
April 21st 75
Hon. John T. Harris
Harrisonburg, Va.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of the
12th instant, requesting assignment
of Dr. Reed, I have the honor to
inform you that Dr. Walter Reed
has been examined and approved by
the Army Medical Board in session
in New York City, for appointment as
Assistant Surgeon, but has not yet
been appointed.

It is contemplated by the
Surgeon General to request that he
be assigned after appointment to
temporary duty at one of the largest
Military posts for instruction.

He declined employment as
Acting Assistant Surgeon until such
time as he could be appointed
Assistant Surgeon, but if he now
desires to go on duty a contract
will be made with him for the pur-
pose above mentioned.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant. H.E. Crosby Chief Clerk.
For the Secretary of War in his absence
